data.title: Git: alert user that he needs to accept the xcode license, in order to use git

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Running on MacOS, I found a tiny glitch with the Source Control feature of VS Code.

Last night I updated Xcode, which also brings Git to MacOS. This morning I made a few changes to my project and went to the Source Control -tab in VS Code to review and commit, but there was no indication of any changes made whatsoever. Also, there wasn't any indication that something was wrong or required my attention.

I was rested well enough to immediately understand I probably have to accept the new Xcode license agreement before Git becomes usable again, but I wish VS Code would at least give me an indication that something is wrong and needs action to be taken.

### Expected

VS Code to let me know that `git` is not working for whatever reason

### What actually happened

I was wondering why my changes aren't shown in Source Control -tab (did I really already commit?!)

data.title: Terminal canvas renderer
data.body:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/34169

- [x] Windows - @alexandrudima 
- [x] Linux - @roblourens 
- [x] macOS - @seanmcbreen 

Complexity: 4

All rendering done by the terminal has moved from a completely DOM-based model to using canvas instead. Here are some things to focus on and look out for:

- Unicode characters, emojis, etc. behave correctly
-,Tweaking the terminal settings, font size/family and line height in particular
- Blurry text, lack of sub-pixel anti-aliasing
- The rows/columns not being the correct size for the panel
- Rows being cut off on the top
- Mouse coordinates when using selection, links and xterm mouse events are accurate
- Changing the window zoom level works as expected

data.title: Check type of token that triggered the quick suggestions
data.body:
Fixes #34863

**Bug**
Quick suggestions currently check the token at the cursor location to determine if we are in a string or comment. Because token spans are setup like: `[start, end)`, this results in us checking the token after the current one. For example, in code like

```
a'string'
```

where `a` was just typed and triggered suggestions, we actually end up grabbing the `'string'` token instead of the `a` token


**Fix**
Check the token one index back from the cursor

data.title: Feature request: Add a setting to prevent extra newline between brackets

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Pressing Enter while the cursor is between empty brackets results in an extra newline before the closing bracket. For example, using `|` to represent the cursor, if we press Enter here

    foo = [|]

we get

    foo = [
        |
    ]

I'd love a setting which allows me to get this instead:

    foo = [
        |]

In case it's not clear, I'm thinking about all kinds of brackets, not just square brackets. Like, whichever ones `editor.autoClosingBrackets` handles.

data.title: report tsserver response error as telemetry
data.body:
Adds a telemetry event to record errors generated by tsserver.

Note that this records all error-responses from tsserver except cancellations. This includes:
* errors thrown while processing a request (we parse out the message and stack in this case)
* requests that do not generate a response when one is expected
* unrecognized JSON commands the server is asked to execute

These events should not be raised often, but part of the reason we would like to get information about these is that we really don't know, since tsserver swallows the errors and continues to run.

data.title: Incorrect html formatting for this in .vue files
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.61.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. set the "editor.formatOnSave": true
2. Save this code as a .vue file with the vetur extension enabled
```
<template>
    <v-icon v-for="n in 5" :key="n">
        {{ n <= details.rating ? 'star' : 'star_border' }}
    </v-icon>
</template>
```

it will format to 
```
<v-icon v-for="n in 5" :key="n">
    {{ n
    <=d etails.rating ? 'star' : 'star_border' }}
</v-icon>
```
which breaks it. I originally created this issue in the vetur repo but they told me the issue is with vscode.
https://github.com/vuejs/vetur/issues/452

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No, needs vetur enabled for .vue support

data.title: Provide way for a language to re-enable editor.quickSuggestions inside of a string or comment
data.body:
**Problem**
Many languages allow embedding language fragments inside of strings. In JavaScript for example:

```ts
`Max int: ${Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER}`
```

While typing within the `${...}` however, we do not show quick suggestions. The root cause is that the template expression is within a string, and the `editor.quickSuggestion.strings` setting explicitly disable quick suggestions within strings.

**Proposal**
We now have a convention of marking languages embedded within strings with the `meta.embeded` scope. This could be used to reset the quick suggestions scopes. 

Here's the scope of the above code:

![screen shot 2017-09-22 at 2 35 25 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12821956/30765205-4f124a28-9fa3-11e7-9e91-318cd0e45bae.png)


In this stack, we'd first see `string.template` which would disable quick suggestions. Then, further up the stack, we see `meta.embedded` which would reset the quick suggestion mode.

data.body:
**Feature request**
In a js/ts file, type out:

```js

 * @|
```

Where you have just finished typing `@`.  At this point we should automatically show suggestions for the jsdoc types. You currently have to trigger them manually

data.title: php syntax highlighting has wrong heredoc termination rules
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:24:39.530Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
Ionide-fsharp|Ion|3.1.0
python|don|0.7.0
reasonml|fre|1.0.0
cpptools|ms-|0.12.4
csharp|ms-|1.12.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

Write a PHP file with the following contents:

$foo = <<<'EOF'
$bar and this and that
EOF.$bar.<<<'EOF'
and some more
EOF;

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3316258/30756751-cc826b00-9f80-11e7-904f-d4481085cae2.png)

**WHAT I EXPECT**

The middle line `EOF.$bar.<<<'EOF'` should all be colored red because it all just a verbatim string, part of the heredoc. It does *not* terminate the first heredoc then start a new heredoc as you might think.

The relevant PHP spec for [heredoc](http://php.net/manual/en/language.types.string.php#language.types.string.syntax.heredoc) explains "It is very important to note that the line with the closing identifier must contain no other characters, except a semicolon (;)". The middle line doesn't meet this restriction and hence isn't a terminator.

And PHP parsers do indeed obey the spec in this respect: http://phpfiddle.org/lite/code/g2xf-edyv

So the syntax-highlighter should too!


Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: [seti] Incorrect icon colors in explorer when using Light themes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
EditorConfig|Edi|0.10.1
cpptools|ms-|0.13.0
cmake-tools|vec|0.10.2
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a folder with a .bat, .xls, or .doc (which have distinguishable colors for their icons)
    * they can be empty files, you just need to get the extension in the filename
2. Switch the theme from Dark+ to Light+
3. Notice that the icons are the wrong colors in the Light+ theme.  (could be a BGR <-> RGB swizzle problem)
    * Windows & Word should be blue. Excel should be green.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

![dark](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12818240/30756839-1c17e5b4-9f81-11e7-918d-d64d129ffcd5.png)
![light](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12818240/30756843-1d98d628-9f81-11e7-8fe0-286e7fc76dc4.png)

data.title: [theming] Use different colors for rendering warning and info markers
data.body:
Both the lsp and vscode api support different severity levels for linter style markers:

- error
- warning
- info

However it seems that the editor theming doesn't actually make a distinction between warning and info (both of them look identical and render as a green squigly underline).

![warning-and-information](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1002156/30756085-e7fe68a0-9f7d-11e7-8665-f3a0ef03050c.png)

A more traditional way of rendering is to use Red for errors, Yellow for warnings and either Green or Blue for info.

I looked at trying to change these looks via the theming support, but as far as I could figure out, the 'equal treatment' of warnings and infos goes down to the theming engine as well. Looking here:

https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/getstarted/theme-color-reference

I find that there are properties like `editorError.foreground` and `editorWarning.foreground`, but there is no `edtitorInfo.foreground` and the info squiglies simply follow the warning color if it is changed.

data.title: Git not found as "installed"
data.body: - VSCode Version: Version 1.17.0-insider (1.17.0-insider) f7962f0682a76516df51de4856f8ccc5d8ad578a - OS Version: macOS 10.12.6 (16G29) Steps to Reproduce: 1. open a git folder 2. nothing else Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Problem pasting JSON that was indented 2 spaces
Option to open cmd or powershell both.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:1.16.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Press Ctrl + ` to open integrated terminal
2. Click + button to open new terminal

There should a option to select cmd or powershell based on option.
